cupcake physics

    August 22nd, 2017

    The Tech Stack

    Tech Stack

    Over the past few weeks I have been working hard to lay some of the groundwork for the site.

    I just wanted to write a quick blog post outlining some of the progress that I have made in the past few weeks. Most of the work that I have done in the past few weeks has been focused on learning the new technologies that I am going to use

    Elm

    Frontend development has frustrated me in the past for a number of reasons. I have a lot of experience .

    After writing a few small apps in Elm, I have decided to use it in development. The more I program in the functional style, the more I grow to love it. Additionally, I especially like the statically typed nature of Elm. I am hoping that this added structure will make my life easier as I develop a potentially complicated frontend.

    Phoenix

    Ruby on Rails was my original choice for the backend of Cupcake Physics. I have enjoyed working with the framework in the past due to the fact that I can develop quality code very quickly. However, I have found issue with some aspects of the framework (e.g. it has a tendency to produce monolithic apps, it couples data persistence very tightly to your business logic, etc.). Since the functional style of programming drew me to the Elm language (in part), I decided to try something new for the backend as well.

    I tried a few different technologies before settling on Elixir for the backend. I have some experience writing Elixir apps coming into this project, so I decided to dive into the Phoenix framework. As other people have mentioned online, the Phoenix framework seems very natural to me coming from a Rails background. I love how powerful pattern matching and the idea of data transformations through piping help elucidate the logic of my code.

    Ansible

    App deploys have always been a bit nerve-wracking for me because I never really knew if everything was going to work at the end of the day. There are so many things to consider including setting up a production server (or VM), installing software, organizing certificates, setting defaults on servers, etc. A large portion of the last month was spent building a robust system through which I can setup the project on a development machine and deploy to production with one click. With the exception of setting up credentials, my goal is that a new developer should be able to join the group with little to no trouble setting up.

    I tried out a few different software in the past (Chef, Puppet, etc.), but I found Ansible to have the right mixture of ease of use and power for my needs.
